docs.lead_paragraph: The American Heart Association is urging all gyms and fitness clubs, especially large centers and those with many elderly members, to install automated external defibrillators, the portable devices that can sometimes shock a stalled heart back to life. In recent years, the defibrillators have been shown to be potent tools in raising the survival rate for people suffering heart attacks: almost 90 percent of those shocked within a minute of collapse survive, a figure that drops 7 percent to 10 percent with every minute, the association said in a statement issued with the American College of Sports Medicine.

headline.main: One Way to Lower the Risk of Exercise

docs.abstract: American Heart Assn urges all gyms and fitness clubs, especially large centers and those with many elderly members, to install automated external heart defibrillators (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Mrs. S. and I first discussed whether she should have a spiral C.T. scan to look for lung cancer, it seemed like the right thing to do. At the time, Mrs. S., a former teacher, was 73 and had no symptoms of lung cancer -- not even a cough.
docs.abstract: Dr Barron Lerner discusses downside of spiral CT scan to detect early-stage lung cancer (Cases column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Can an otherwise healthy 58-year-old man die from a bad cold? He can, and he did. Through an unfortunate cascade of events, starting with a missed diagnosis of viral pneumonia, Tom Wilson, a systems analyst for Westinghouse, went from bad to worse until every major organ system -- kidneys, liver, lungs and finally his heart -- stopped working.

headline.main: New Hope for Taming Deadly Septic Shock

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on septic shock, abnormal inflammation and clotting that can quickly lead to major organ failure and death; notes condition, despite use of potent antibiotics and advanced resuscitative equipment, remains leading cause of death in hospital intensive care units; notes Food and Drug Administration has granted Eli Lilly license to market Xigris, first drug proven to reduce mortality from severe sepsis; diagram (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Muscle tics and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, commonly called A.D.H.D., often go together, a fact that has complicated treatment. Doctors have worried that the stimulants prescribed for the hyperactivity will worsen the twitching that comes with conditions like Tourette's syndrome. But last week, the journal Neurology released ahead of schedule a study that its authors hope will lay those fears to rest.

headline.main: Relief Found for Children's Dual Ailments

docs.abstract: Study by University of Rochester Medical Center researcher Dr Roger Kurlan and others, published in journal Neurology, finds that Ritalin and Clonadine, drugs used most often to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, reduce, over long run, muscle tics associated with ADHD (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bicycle accidents that seem minor can cause serious abdominal injuries in children, say researchers in Philadelphia who have designed a handlebar that they hope will make biking safer. In a typical low-speed bike crash, the bicycle hits an obstruction like a rock or a curb and comes to a stop. The cyclist instinctively turns the handlebar to regain balance, causing one end to swing toward the midriff. As the cyclist tips forward and falls, the closer end of the handlebar digs into the rider's abdomen while the opposite end hits the ground. The impact can injure the kidneys, liver and spleen.

headline.main: Device Aims to Cut Injuries From Handlebars

docs.abstract: Researchers at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, noting that children can suffer serious abdominal injuries in apparently minor bike accidents, design spring-mounted handlebar that compresses on impact; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 1980's, as the number of babies born with H.I.V. increased at a soaring rate, Harlem became the epicenter of a ''boarder baby'' crisis. These infants were the offspring of H.I.V.-positive women, many of them addicted to drugs. Often extremely sick, the babies were frequently either given away or taken away; most were not expected to reach their fifth birthdays. But by the early 90's, H.I.V. births began to drop nationwide, and by the mid-90's, the numbers decreased sharply because of new antiviral medication that prevented transmission of the virus from mother to child.

headline.main: Rescued H.I.V. Babies Face New Problems as Teenagers

docs.abstract: Harlem Hospital Center pediatrics director Stephen Nicholas and Family Care clinic director Elaine Abrams, in article published in February issue of American Journal of Public Health, describe high percentage of older children born with HIV suffering from severe behavioral problems and mental illness; see need for specialized services, particularly in light of small but increasing number of adolescents who are being rejected by parents who adopted them as babies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In August 2000, Jean Rettura was lying on an operating table at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, about to undergo surgery, when the anesthesiologist looked down and said, from behind his mask, ''You were my Spanish teacher.'' ''Did I pass you?'' she asked. He said she had, and then added that he was sorry she needed surgery.

headline.main: Tests for Breast Cancer Gene Raise Hard Choices

docs.abstract: Article on hard choices that people carrying mutation in gene called BRCA2, which carries greatly increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancer, must make about whether to be tested and what to do if test is positive; researchers from Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, in article in current issue of Journal of Clinical Oncology, describe exerpience of 251 BRCA carriers tested and counseled between May 1995 and November 2000; photos; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People with excessively sweaty palms may have their genes, and not their nervousness, to blame, a new study suggests. The study of the condition, formally known as primary palmar hyperhidrosis, found that 63 percent of patients seeking a surgical treatments reported other family members were also afflicted.

headline.main: Sweaty Palms: Not Just a Case of Nerves

docs.abstract: University of California at Los Angeles study, published in Journal of Vascular Surgery, finds genetic link among people with primary pamar hyperhidrosis, or excessively sweaty palms; findings suggest that problem is more widespread than believed; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women who never ate fish were more than three times as likely to deliver prematurely or have underweight babies as women who ate fish at least once a week, a new Danish study has found. An earlier study of women in the Faroe Islands, where fish makes up a large part of the daily diet, had found unusually few premature or low-birth-weight babies there, and some experiments with fish oil supplements have suggested that the kinds of fat found in fish, known as n-3 fatty acids, can play a role in the difference.

headline.main: Of Healthy Babies and Fishy Diets

docs.abstract: Study conducted at Skejby University Hospital in Denmark involving more than 8,000 pregnant women finds that those who never ate fish were more than three times as likely to deliver prematurely or have underweight babies as those who ate fish at least once a week; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Pregnant women who never ate fish were more than three times as likely to deliver prematurely or have underweight babies as women who ate fish at least once a week, a new Danish study has found.    An earlier study of women in the Faroe Islands,...

docs.lead_paragraph: As chickenpox begins to disappear in the United States, another potentially dangerous disease for children, pertussis, has been bouncing back, according to two recent studies from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Pertussis, a bacterial infection that brings on a severe cough, was a common killer of children before a vaccine was introduced in the late 1940's. But since hitting a low of 1,010 cases in 1976, incidence of the disease has been creeping up, rising most steeply in the last decade, according to the center's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report. The number of cases reached 6,564 in 1997 and 7,867 in 2000.
docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention releases two studies indicating that pertussis, childhood bacterial infection, has been rising steeply in last decade; drawing (M)
